blog.name: awilliamswrites
blog.title: A. Williams Writes
blog.description: Writing, Mental Health, Thoughts on Media and Current Events.   Pisces // 26 // INFP-T

title: Why I Love Captain Marvel
body:
There are two main points that I’ve seen brought up as to why Captain Marvel was supposedly a bad movie.

The first is that the acting was bad or wooden. To that I can only say “Did you watch the same movie I did?” I thought the acting was great, and while I could try to explain why everyone who thinks otherwise is wrong (I’m kidding, I know it’s subjective) I’m not going to. What one person thinks is a heart-wrenching scene another person will think is over-the-top and narmy. So, to those who found the acting bad, I can only say “your loss” for not enjoying it.

The next bit has a spoiler, so you can read more under the cut.

The other point is that Carol Danvers is over-powered. Look, I get it when people complain about the movie and say “she’s too powerful” “there weren’t any stakes” “she was never in danger.” I really do. I majored in English. I understand the importance of conflict. But… we’ve had innumerable stories where the Forces of Good only scrape out a win by the skin of their teeth, and lemme tell you it was an absolute breath of fresh air to me how in this movie Good just totally outclassed, outgunned, and obliterated the bad guys. It was awesome. It was joyous. I loved it.

I could go on and on about why I love this. Everywhere you look, in real life and fiction, the forces of evil often outweigh, outmaneuver, and overwhelm the good. Even systems we set up to help people become bogged down or inefficient or go so far as to get in the way of themselves so that they become more of a detriment than a help. There is never enough time, energy, money, or power for anyone or any group of people to just … unleash all the potential for good that they have. I myself have clinical depression, and like a poison it stops me from not only doing all the good that I could be doing, but sometimes all that is necessary for me to just function in a day as I waste it instead by staying in bed until 4pm or whenever. (I don’t know if I should go so far as to call depression a force of evil, but…eh.)

Even though I haven’t brought it to the forefront of my mind until now, I guess I saw a little of myself in Captain Marvel, where that inhibitor on her neck is whatever is holding me (or anyone else) back from being their best, most powerful selves. So the payoff, the climax where she is released from that inhibitor and is immediately not only super powerful, but quite literally a source of great light (such great symbolism!), and not only that but that she is suddenly the most powerful being around…I felt true joy watching that, knowing that evil didn’t stand a chance against her. 

And since I was connected to her emotionally, (since I wasn’t somehow off-put by her perfectly good acting) I got to feel, vicariously, even if only for a short while, that evil couldn’t stand a chance against me.

I can acknowledge the validity of the complaints against her power level but if it wasn’t clear already I just don’t care. Take your criticisms elsewhere, please, because I love Captain Marvel.

summary: Endgame is gonna end with Carol flying in at warp speed and throat punching Thanos so hard that his throat explodes on impact...
body: Endgame is gonna end with Carol flying in at warp speed and throat punching Thanos so hard that his throat explodes on impact killing him instantly and when asked about all the snapped heroes and people she laughs and then whips out a 90s boombox and starts breaking it down to Motown Philly by Boys II Men and then the after credit scene is Tony sobbing into a bottle of gin while Carol break dances to Holla Back Girl in the background

I'm a Lurker Fangirl.  If you think you've seen me, then I haven't been doing my job properly.
Icon/Avatar credit to fade from livejournal

body:
Saw Captain Marvel today

I think Black Panther was better, but goddamn CM was 1000x more amazing than Civil War.

About the biggest thing that threw me out of the movie was the dude on the motorcycle actually leaving Carol alone, rather than getting up into her space or giving her shit about ignoring him.

ALSO CUTEST KITTY ALERT IT’S SO ADORABLE WITH ITS GINGERNESS AND MEOWS AND DEVOURING THE ENEMY.

summary: i saw captain marvel this weekend and two things stuck out to me the most: one, that handsome fella Goose was absolutely the...
question: i saw captain marvel this weekend and two things stuck out to me the most: one, that handsome fella Goose was absolutely the Star of the Show, and two, carol danvers and maria rambeau are peak mid 90's wlw, oh my god, they have a daughter who spilled KETCHUP on a LEATHER JACKET. iconic. when will we ever be so blessed again
answer: RIGHT?! I feel ya, nonny. They’re m a r r i e d.

Steampunk tea dreams: Fuzzy & Silky's Tea Time, WIP: Escapist Realities. My husband is a published author! Future That Never Was by Kin S. Law

summary: Y'all tumblrs afraid of the military paraphernalia of Captain Marvel were straight up lying.
body:
Y'all tumblrs afraid of the military paraphernalia of Captain Marvel were straight up lying.

This was an homage to the air force, not the military, army or any such thing. To the people, the women who can fly now. This focused on the years just before 1993, when women were finally allowed to fly in combat missions. 1976, women were allowed to fly but only in 1993 were they allowed combat missions. And the music was so 90s. All the commercials and imagery were strictly air force imagery, which is the training you need before becoming an astronaut. You want women in space? You need women to fly.

Do you realize that as a young girl, I was watching Apollo 13, Armeggedon, Independence Day, Space Cowboys, these films about Air Force guys turned astronauts and not being able to argue about why there weren’t any women astronauts, cause it was literally not allowed for women to get the experience they’d need. I couldn’t argue about representation cause it wasn’t even realistic and irl was not representing. Old people with heart issues made more sense than a young woman.

Spoilers ahead:

Captain Marvel was even about propaganda screwing with her. Are you kidding me? Y'all lied. I’m not even going to say anything else cause I don’t want to ruin it.

And as for production value, it was right there with a Thor origin, not the trilogy cause that last one was epic and not to be repeated easily. It deux ex machina’d all day long cause that’s what 90s comics did! Comic book writers would write themselves into a corner with a cliffhanger and have to do something crazy to get out of it. It warms my old nerdy heart to see it done in the big screen too.

And honestly, we’re all just waiting on Captain Marvel to deux ex machina our way out of this Thanos mess anyway. It is cathartic, it is epic and powerful, it is joyous too. Y'all. Don’t sleep on this. This ain’t a filler. Ant-man was a filler. But we always have such low expectations on that one that we always get blown away anyway.

I must admit, I did cry 2x. Y'all spoiled me on the I shall rise bit, but with the music and timing of revelations, it still got me. I’ve seen a ton of men and boys get up after being hit down, and I love every one of those moments. But seeing all the versions of Carol doing it made me realize I had never seen that many girls or women doing the same power move in a movie without a man or boy helping us up before. Not that often, not even 5 times in my history of movie watching. Damn, that ain’t right. Yes, I’ll take 5 more versions of Carol doing it, please and thank you.

blog.name: wildnoutinwildemount
blog.title: 🎶 gigi, hit the track! 🎶
blog.description: - Randa - 27 - TX - Cis she/her - My Paypal - Gaymer - Full-time fangirl - Writer/aspiring producer - Current obsessions: Critical Role, Killing Eve, & the MCU - Lifelong fan of superheroes, Star Wars, & fantasy - History buff, feminist, LGBT activist.

summary: Ever since I saw the article that mentioned the Russo brothers have a plan on “how to handle” Captain Marvel’s powers in...
body:
Ever since I saw the article that mentioned the Russo brothers have a plan on “how to handle” Captain Marvel’s powers in Endgame, I’ve just been super worried about them nerfing her because like… in this type of story, it isn’t even necessary. If she had showed up BEFORE the Snap, I can sort of understand because her and Thor and Wanda… yeah they could probably kill Thanos with relative ease. I mean, any one of them alone SHOULD be able to do it, according to their power sets but WRITERS, RIGHT?! 

But she is arriving AFTER the Snap, so her powers aren’t too OP in the sense of fixing what happened. It’s way more complicated now than just stopping Thanos. He already did it. Now they have to undo it and that isn’t as simple as kicking his ass or killing him. So I am really praying they don’t nerf her for no reason.

And even though I am a hardcore Captain Marvel fan above probably all Avengers, I will say I don’t think she should be the one to land the killing blow. I DO want her to be a big part of beating him, and I WANT HER TO HAVE SO MUCH SCREENTIME. But I think it’s very important for the story that has unfolded so far for Tony, Nebula, and Thor to be instrumental in Thanos’ undoing. They’ve lost the most because of him. Ultimately I want everyone to have their time to shine and for the movie to give everyone their due. I want to see everyone at the height of their glory!

reblog.comment:
Ever since I saw the article that mentioned the Russo brothers have a plan on “how to handle” Captain Marvel’s powers in Endgame, I’ve just been super worried about them nerfing her because like… in this type of story, it isn’t even necessary. If she had showed up BEFORE the Snap, I can sort of understand because her and Thor and Wanda… yeah they could probably kill Thanos with relative ease. I mean, any one of them alone SHOULD be able to do it, according to their power sets but WRITERS, RIGHT?! 

But she is arriving AFTER the Snap, so her powers aren’t too OP in the sense of fixing what happened. It’s way more complicated now than just stopping Thanos. He already did it. Now they have to undo it and that isn’t as simple as kicking his ass or killing him. So I am really praying they don’t nerf her for no reason.

And even though I am a hardcore Captain Marvel fan above probably all Avengers, I will say I don’t think she should be the one to land the killing blow. I DO want her to be a big part of beating him, and I WANT HER TO HAVE SO MUCH SCREENTIME. But I think it’s very important for the story that has unfolded so far for Tony, Nebula, and Thor to be instrumental in Thanos’ undoing. They’ve lost the most because of him. Ultimately I want everyone to have their time to shine and for the movie to give everyone their due. I want to see everyone at the height of their glory!

summary: For those worried that Captain Marvel is too OP
title: For those worried that Captain Marvel is too OP
body:
This article pretty much covers everything. She IS essentially the Superman of the MCU, but even Superman has some weaknesses despite being one of the most powerful beings out there. Same for Carol. 

Thus far, the MCU has neatly sidestepped the “Superman problem” that the various DC universes have (why bother calling any other superhero when Supes is almost always the best man for the job?). But with the cosmically powerful Captain Marvel in town, that balance might be broken. That’s probably why Marvel Studios head honcho Kevin Feige has explained that while she might have been all-powerful in her solo movie (and she’s presumably going to pack a serious punch in Avengers: Endgame), they’ll still find limitations for her. In an interview with /Film, he said:

“Well, the point of [Captain Marvel] was to see her exactly as you said, unleashed, unchained. What happens when she taps into her full potential not being held back? So it was not the time to hold back. It was not the time to emphasize limitations or loss. We’d seen that over the course of the rest of the movie. We wanted to see her cut loose. In future stories, well, none of the Marvel characters are immortal. Even ones that seem immortal, some people might be very hard to kill, but nobody’s unkillable. So if we’re lucky enough to see future adventures with Captain Marvel, of course there will be limitations and there will be Achilles heels and there will be things that we learn and see that it’s not as easy as a slicing through whatever she wants to at any point. But this wasn’t the time to accentuate that.”

This is something comic book writers have had to tackle over the course of her history in the Marvel Universe. A common weakness is that while Captain Marvel might have immense powers, she’s essentially still the human being Carol Danvers, and as such, she can be mind-controlled, brainwashed or psychologically manipulated. More prosaically, just as she was given powers, they can also be taken away. This most famously happened in the comics when the mutant Rogue absorbed Ms. Marvel’s Kree powers. In addition (much like Superman), she has no defense against magical attacks, so if she did go haywire, Doctor Strange might be a good bet to rein her in.

This is super exciting because it means they have to bring in bigger and badder threats for her to combat. I’m looking forward to it!

blog.name: thisiscomics
blog.title: A Panel A Day (more or less)
blog.description: I probably read too many comics. Here are some highlights. If you like, go give money to the creators.

summary: It’s a pretty simple image, just a silhouette filled with a star field, but it really works to create a sense of wonder: Carol...
body:
It’s a pretty simple image, just a silhouette filled with a star field, but it really works to create a sense of wonder: Carol surrounded by alien children, all of them represented as part of the universe, made of the universe, with the Captain Marvel logo a central source of light.

While the captions talk of Carol and her power, which suggests strength and combat, the image shows a hero that is truly part of the universe (perhaps explaining why she is ‘out there’ somewhere as often as she is based on Earth); someone that cares more about what makes us the same rather than fighting against another because they are different. Whether because of her Kree connections, or simply because of who she is, she is open to existence as a whole, feeling a unity with everything. The book’s title represents this utopian ideal of a nation made of all species and positions Carol as the opposite of the insularity and hatred that was about to come to Earth in the Secret Empire event series.

From The Mighty Captain Marvel 3, by Margaret Stohl, Ramon Rosanas, Michael Garland, Marcio Menyz & Joe Caramagna, reprinted in The Mighty Captain Marvel: Alien Nation

tags: sometimes I see people insulting the god of the amazons
and whether they are or not
summary: 1/2: I think you might have misunderstood that one post about captain marvel makeup in endgame and comparing it to the amazons...
question: 1/2: I think you might have misunderstood that one post about captain marvel makeup in endgame and comparing it to the amazons from ww. The pic on the left was the patty jenkins one and the one on the right with little to no armor and all that skin was the dude director one. You’re right about the patty jenkins one being accurate and showed skin too but it wasn’t sexualized like the inaccurate dude director one and that’s what the post was talking about. That the
answer:
2/2: woman directed movie (ww/captain marvel) didn’t have grossly sexualized costumes (ww) and a face full of makeup/tight clothes (captain marvel) but in the team movies directed by dudes that was no longer the case. It wasn’t dissing ww/patty jenkins, it was dissing the dude director that came after

—-

Oh shoot dude, thanks I was super confused, I haven’t seen captain marvel yet so I can’t really hold an opinion but thanks for clearing this up!

—-
